Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story:
This Sunday morning, I sat at the kitchen table, coffee cooling in my hands, as my husband paced the floor. He was anxious, wrestling with a decision at work that could change everything for us. He looked at me, eyes searching for reassurance, and I knew he needed me—my words, my presence, my support. I wanted to be there for him, to listen and help him sort through his worries, just as a loving wife should.

But as I glanced at the clock, I remembered the church service starting soon. I hadn’t been in weeks, and I felt the weight of my faith pressing on me—the expectation to worship, to be part of the community, to honor God with my time. I wanted to go, to reconnect with my spiritual family, to feel that sense of belonging and peace.

My heart tugged in two directions. I could see the hope in my husband’s eyes, and I could feel the quiet call of my faith. I sat there, torn, unsure which part of myself to honor in that moment.
